column1: The solar wind is a stream of charged particles released from the upper atmosphere of the Sun. This plasma consists of mostly electrons
column2: protons and alpha particles with energies usually between 1.5 and 10 keV; embedded in the solar-wind plasma is the interplanetary magnetic field. The solar wind varies in density
column3: temperature and speed over time and over solar longitude. Its particles can escape the Sun's gravity because of their high energy
column4: from the high temperature of the corona and magnetic
column5: electrical and electromagnetic phenomena in it.The solar winds flow outward supersonically at varying speeds depending on their origin reaching up to around one million miles per hour to great distances
column6: filling a region known as the heliosphere
column7: an enormous bubble-like volume surrounded by the interstellar medium. Other related phenomena include the aurora (northern and southern lights)
column8: the plasma tails of comets that always point away from the Sun
column9: and geomagnetic storms that can change the direction of magnetic field lines.
